sub_topic: Finding the Fourier series of a function with a finite number of discontinuities
message_1:
Given the periodic function $f(t) = \begin{cases} 
      1 & 0 \leq t<1 \\
      -1 & 1\leq t<2 \\
      0 & \text{otherwise} \\
   \end{cases}$, find its Fourier series up to the $3^{rd}$ harmonic.
message_2:
To find the Fourier series of the given function, we need to find the coefficients $a_0, a_n$, and $b_n$. The function has a period of $T = 2$, so we will use the following formulas:

$$a_0 = \frac{1}{T} \int_{0}^{T} f(t) dt$$

$$a_n = \frac{2}{T} \int_{0}^{T} f(t) \cos(\frac{2\pi nt}{T}) dt$$

$$b_n = \frac{2}{T} \int_{0}^{T} f(t) \sin(\frac{2\pi nt}{T}) dt$$

First, we find $a_0$:

$$a_0 = \frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{2} f(t) dt = \frac{1}{2} \left(\int_{0}^{1} 1 dt + \int_{1}^{2} -1 dt\right) = \frac{1}{2} (1 - 1) = 0$$

Now, we find $a_n$:

$$a_n = \frac{2}{2} \int_{0}^{2} f(t) \cos(\pi nt) dt = \int_{0}^{1} 1 \cdot \cos(\pi nt) dt - \int_{1}^{2} 1 \cdot \cos(\pi nt) dt$$

Since the function is odd, all $a_n$ coefficients will be zero. Now, we find $b_n$:

$$b_n = \int_{0}^{1} \sin(\pi nt) dt - \int_{1}^{2} \sin(\pi nt) dt$$

For $n = 1, 2, 3$, we have:

$$b_1 = \left[-\frac{1}{\pi}\cos(\pi t)\right]_0^1 - \left[-\frac{1}{\pi}\cos(\pi t)\right]_1^2 = \frac{2}{\pi}$$

$$b_2 = \left[-\frac{1}{2\pi}\cos(2\pi t)\right]_0^1 - \left[-\frac{1}{2\pi}\cos(2\pi t)\right]_1^2 = 0$$

$$b_3 = \left[-\frac{1}{3\pi}\cos(3\pi t)\right]_0^1 - \left[-\frac{1}{3\pi}\cos(3\pi t)\right]_1^2 = \frac{2}{3\pi}$$

So, the Fourier series up to the $3^{rd}$ harmonic is:

$$f(t) = \frac{2}{\pi}\sin(\pi t) + \frac{2}{3\pi}\sin(3\pi t)$$
